the attachment m any motorcycle carrying a passenger other than in a sidecar or enclosed cab shall be equipped with footrests for the passenger n no person shall operate any motorcycle with handlebars so positioned that the hands of the operator when upon the grips are above shoulder height when the operator is sitting astride the vehicle seat with the vehicle in an upright position o no minor shall operate or ride nor shall the operator permit a minor to ride upon a motorcycle unless he is wearing protective headgear securely fastened on his head and of a type which complies with standards established by the superintendent this subsection does not apply to persons riding within an enclosed cab nor to persons operating or riding a moped this subsection only applies to motorcycles used on public highways streets and thoroughfares p any person operating a motorcycle or pedestrian vehicle shall have the headlamps of the motorcycle or pedestrian vehicle activated at all times including daylight hours q operators of motorcycles operating in an officially authorized parade are exempt from subsections e o of this section r the superintendent is authorized to approve or disapprove protective headgear required herein and to issue and enforce regulations establishing standards and specifications for the approval thereof and to the sale and use of the equipment as provided for other vehicle safety equipment the standard for protective headgear shall meet or exceed the z9011971 standard of the american national standards institute however all existing equipment meeting the z9011966 standard of the american national standards institute shall be accepted s this section applies to motordriven cycles unless otherwise provided    motordriven cycles no person shall operate or allow to be operated upon any public street alley or highway within the corporate limits of the city any of the following vehicles powered by an electric or gas motorengine to wit 1 any motorized bicycle without pedals 2 pocket motorcycle 3 minibike 4 gocart 5 scooter 6 skateboard 7 allterrain vehicle 8 any offroad vehicle which cannot be registered for operation on any public street or highway this section excludes mopeds motorized bicycles with pedals for nonmotorized operation and persons operating an electric or gas powered vehicle due to permanent or temporary disabilities in compliance with ws statute  multipurpose vehicles   multipurpose vehicles multipurpose vehicle means a motor vehicle that is a designed to travel on at least four 4 wheels in contact with the ground b has an unladen weight of at least three hundred 300 pounds but less than three thousand 3000 pounds c has an upright seat or saddle for the driver which is mounted at least twentyfour 24 inches from the ground and d has an identifying number as defined by ws 311101aix examples include i offroad recreational vehicles ii electric powered vehicles iii golf carts golf carts are not an mpv when they are being used on a golf course or when they are being used for special events any properly licensed and insured multipurpose vehicle may be operated on public streets with a properly licensed driver the vehicle and driver will operate under the same traffic regulations as a motor vehicle    alternate lighting for slowmoving vehicles any motor vehicle may be operated under the conditions specified in this title when equipped with two 2 lighted lamps upon the front thereof capable of revealing persons and objects one hundred 100 feet ahead in lieu of head lamps otherwise required under this act if the vehicle is not operated at a speed in excess of twenty 20 miles per hour    pedestrian vehicles a every pedestrian vehicle operated upon a highway shall be equipped with the following equipment i a horn meeting the requirements of m of this title  ii at least one 1 headlamp of either a singlebeam or multiplebeam type which shall be of sufficient intensity to reveal a person or a vehicle at a distance of not less than one hundred 100 feet when operated at any speed less than twentyfive 25 miles per hour  iii two 2 tail lamps which shall be so wired as to be lighted whenever the headlamp is lighted and which when lighted shall emit a red light plainly visible from a distance of at least one hundred 100 feet to the rear  iv rear stop lamps and turn signals conforming to the requirements of the superintendent  v a brake which conforms to the performance requirements of l of this title  and vi a reflectorized flag mounted in a bracket permanently affixed to the vehicle the flag when mounted shall be visible from all directions at a height of not less than fortyeight 48 inches nor more than seventytwo 72 inches measured from the level ground upon which the vehicle stands and shall conform to the following requirements a be constructed of durable allweather type material  b be orange in color  c be triangular in shape with a minimum base length of eight and onehalf 812 inches and a minimum side length of eleven and onehalf 1112 inches  truck routes and truck parking   applicability of title generally all commercial trucks over ten thousand 10000 pounds gross vehicle weight within the city shall be operated only over and along the truck routes established in this title    exceptions this chapter shall not prohibit a operations on street of destination this chapter shall not prohibit the operation of a power unit having three 3 or more axles regardless of weight and used in combination upon entering the street where necessary to the conduct of business at a destination point within the city limits provided streets upon which such traffic is permitted are used until reaching the intersection nearest the destination point b emergency vehicles the operation of emergency vehicles upon any street in the city c detoured vehicles the operation of such trucks upon any officially established detour in any case where such truck could lawfully be operated upon the street for which such detour is established    1 11132018   size and weight limits prescribedpneumatic tires required no vehicle which exceeds the size and weight limitations imposed by wyoming statutes or any city ordinance shall be operated on the streets of the city if a special permit is obtained from the state highway department and the route does not depart from the state highway system the city shall accept the state permit  2 11132018 editors note  2 adopted nov 13 201 amended   in its entirety to read as herein set out former   pertained to weight limits prescribedpneumatic tires required and derived from adopted aug 13 2012   authority to weigh vehicles the chief of police shall have the authority to require any person driving or in control of any commercial vehicle operating on the streets of the city and which heshe has reason to believe is overloaded as provided for in this chapter to proceed to any public or private scale available for the purpose of weighing at the expense of the company or operator of the vehicle and determining whether this chapter has been complied with    3 11132018   truck routes established the following truck routes are established within the city a outside originoutside destination all trucks over ten thousand 10000 pounds gross vehicle weight having origination and destination points outside the city shall not enter upon any city street or roadway except for the purpose of obtaining support services including but not limited to food gas and repairs  provided that such trucks shall use only approved truck routes within the city limits as defined in subsection b of this section b truck traffic within the city limits i outside origin a the following truck routes are established within the city for use by trucks having their destination within the city limits or originating within the city limits or which qualify under subsection a of this section i richards street  ii south riverbend drive  iii north 4th street from highway 59 bypass to cedar street  iv cedar street from north 4th street to county road no 52 east antelope  v highway 59  vi highway 94 b once inside the destination point all such commercial trucks entering the city for destination point in the city shall proceed only over an established truck route and shall deviate only at the intersection within the street upon which such traffic permitted nearest to the destination point a deviating truck shall return to the truck route by the shortest possible route c multiple inside destination points all such trucks entering the city for multiple destination points shall proceed only over established truck routes and shall deviate only at the intersection with the street upon which such traffic is permitted nearest to the first destination point upon leaving the first destination point a deviating truck shall proceed to other destination points by the shortest direction and only over streets upon which such traffic is permitted upon leaving the last destination point a deviating truck shall return to the truck route by the shortest permissible route ii inside originoutside destination point all such trucks on a trip originating in the city and traveling in the city for a destination point outside the city shall proceed by the shortest direction over streets on which such traffic is permitted to a truck route as herein established    4 11132018   chief of police to maintain map the chief of police shall keep and maintain accurate maps setting out truck routes and streets upon which traffic is permitted  the maps shall be kept on file in the office of the chief of police at city hall and shall be available to the public    4 11132018   truck parking a no person shall park any commercial truck over ten thousand 10000 pounds gross vehicle weight upon any street or alley in the city except in those areas designated as either business or industrial b no person shall park any commercial truck of any type loaded with lp gas explosives livestock petroleum products or radioactive material on any street or alley in the city except when in the process of loading or unloading c the chief of police may cause any truck as described in subsection b of this section to be towed to such a place as is determined safe as if such truck is left unattended or parked in violation of subsection b any and all fees for such towing shall be the responsibility of the driver andor owner of the truck d truck parking shall comply with the requirements of the unified land development    8102015  railroads   construction and maintenance of street crossings ditches and tracks any railroad company operating within the city shall do the following a construct keep clean and maintain suitable approaches at each street crossing so that any tracks may be readily crossed by persons and vehicles at each street crossing  b construct keep open and keep in repair all necessary ditches side drains sewers and culverts so that filthy or stagnant water cannot stand on the premises or rightofway of such railroad company  c construct and maintain its tracks in such manner that the natural drainage of the adjacent property shall not be impaired    obstruction of streets and crossings by locomotive engine or cars no railroad nor railroad company railroad engineer conductor or other person shall cause or allow any locomotive engine car or train of cars to stop in or remain upon any street or railroad crossing within the city for a longer period than ten 10 minutes at any one time  provided that in case of a collision or other unavoidable accident on any or either of such crossings a reasonable time shall be allowed to remove any obstruction that may be caused thereby should any street of the city be and remain obstructed wholly or in part by any railroad train or railway cars locomotive engines or other railroad equipment for and during the period of ten 10 minutes it shall be the duty of each railroad or railway company upon whose lines or road such obstruction may occur their agents and employees and persons in charge of such train locomotive engine or equipment on or before the expiration of such ten 10 minutes when from any cause the entire train cannot be propelled or moved off of any street obstructed as stated to cause such cars as are or may be on or near such crossings to be uncoupled and moved from off the street or crossing in such manner as to leave such crossing entirely free and unobstructed and such train when again coupled shall be moved forthwith off the crossing    reserved editors note  adopted   repealed   in its entirety former   pertained to whistle to be blown when locomotive engine in motion and was derived from adopted    loitering by persons under fifteen years of age near railroad depots tracks or platforms it is unlawful for any child under the age of fifteen 15 years to loiter about the railroad depots within the limits of this city or to go upon the platform or railroad tracks in the vicinity of such depot unless in company with his parent guardian or person having such child in charge or authorized to do so by such parent or guardian in charge of such child  penalty   designated any person convicted under this title shall be fined any sum not to exceed seven hundred fifty dollars $75000  title 12  streets sidewalks and public places excavations and obstructions of streets and sidewalks   definitions for the purposes of this chapter the following terms phrases words and their derivations shall have the meanings given in this section applicant means any person making written application to the city engineer for excavation or street closure permits hereunder excavation work means the excavation and other work permitted under an excavation permit and required to be performed under this chapter and where a trencher backhoe boring machine jackhammer cable plow or any other methods or equipment are used to excavate or disturb lands within the rightofway of a city street as defined herein improvements means and includes but is not limited to water lines sanitary and storm sewer lines street lighting traffic signal systems traffic signs topsoil sod trees public utility lines and systems and street improvements including subgrade base pavement or other surfacing curbs gutters medians sidewalks and all of the various appurtenances of these improvements person means any individual person partnership corporation association governmental corporation estate trust or two 2 or more individual persons having a joint or common interest responsible property owner means that property owners whose property is adjacent and contingent to the affected property where public improvement repairs are required settlement means any variation of the finished street surface from the testing edge of a tenfoot straight edge between any two 2 contact points with the surface sidewalk means any portion of a street between the curb line and the adjacent property line that is improved and intended for use by pedestrians street means that portion of an easement of ground designated and dedicated to the public to accommodate a thoroughfare avenue road highway boulevard parkway drive circle court lane alley or any similar use within the city  5102010   1 2122018   barriers and lights on closed streets a whenever it becomes necessary for the public works director to close traffic to any street or alley or any portion thereof for the purpose of making repairs or improvements it shall be the duty of the public works director to erect or cause to be erected suitable barriers across such street or alley which barriers shall have appropriate warning lights in operation from dusk until daylight b it is unlawful for any person to drive upon or into any barricade repairs or improvements or to remove or cause to be removed any part of such barricade or warning device part 1984 prior code  265   prohibited obstructions designated a no person shall erect build or set up in the town in whole or in part any fence signpost shop or any other building or obstruction whatever in or upon any street alley sidewalk or other public place nor shall any sign awning or other obstruction be suspended from any building into or over any sidewalk street or alley so as to obstruct or suspend in or over any portion of the street other than the sidewalk line all awnings including the aprons thereof and all suspensions from any building and all suspensions whatever over any sidewalk shall be not less than ten 10 feet above the sidewalk b no person or corporation shall place or cause to be placed upon or over any sidewalk in the town or suspend over or place or deposit in any street or sidewalk goods wares and merchandise for sale show or otherwise beyond or from the line of the lot where such goods may be placed or suspended c with the exception of wires required for the operation and service of a public utility no person shall install erect or extend wires of any kind across any street alley or public way if such wires are installed erected or extended they shall be removed within thirty 30 days by and at the expense of the owner or person responsible therefor d nothing in this section however shall prohibit the mayor or the town council in their discretion from giving permission for the erection of temporary signs banners or necessary obstructions    signs and awnings in or over federalaid highways a no person shall permit erect or cause to be erected any awnings canopies marquees advertising signs or similar installations that extend into over or across any primary secondary urban or other classes of federalaid highways within the town all awnings canopies marquees and advertising signs shall not be less than two 2 feet behind the curbline with a minimum clearance of ten 10 feet from the sidewalk to the bottom of the signs all supports braces guy wires or similar supporting devices shall not be in or on any established highway rightofway b all awnings canopies marquees advertising signs or similar installations which are in place prior to  which are supported entirely from outside the highway rightofway may be permitted to remain under a revocable permit from the town in accordance with the limitations and restrictions contained therein but subject to complete compliance with this section in the event extensive repair or maintenance of such awnings canopies marquees and advertising signs is instituted by the owner    permit required for excavations a it is unlawful for any person to dig up break excavate bore tunnel undermine or in any manner disturb any street or to make or cause to be made any excavation in or under the surface of any street sidewalk alley or other public ground or in any street rightofway unless such person has first obtained an excavation permit from the city as provided herein any work done within the city limits as permitted by this chapter shall only be performed by a contractor appropriately licensed by the city of douglas  and must be approved by the city prior to commencement no routine replacement of utility lines connections or structures of any kind including but not limited to gas telephone or other facilities shall be permitted within one 1 year after initial surfacing or resurfacing of any street routine replacement shall mean ordinary or predictable replacement of utility lines street cut permits are not required for the following types of work 1 removal and replacement of concrete curb gutter sidewalk curbcut or curbwalk 2 geotechnical work associated with cityfunded street water or sewer improvements 3 installation of electrical sewer andor gas underground utilities in conjunction with building mechanical plumbing or electrical permits for buildings when performing the excavation work on private property 4 normal street maintenance work being performed by the public works department 5 maintenance and repair of existing utilities by city maintenance crews required for the operation of the public utilities system 6 the contractor performing the work shall erect suitable barriers having appropriate warning lights in operation from dusk until daylight b it is unlawful for any person to drive into disturb remove or cause to be removed any such barrier warning light or parts thereof c any violation of this section may result in the assessment of a fine of up to seven hundred fifty dollars $75000 part 1984 prior code  268  5102010   2 2122018   permit issuance fee a permit fees a fee of thirty dollars $3000 shall be charged by the city for the issuance of a required excavation permit whenever any work for which a permit is required by this chapter has commenced without a permit a fee of sixty dollars $6000 shall be charged to the applicant by the city b emergencies in the event of an emergency arising whereby an excavation is made and no permit has been issued then the contractor doing the excavation shall as soon as possible report same to the city not later than the next working day and secure a permit c completion of work the public works director shall determine the number of days allowed to complete permitted excavations andor repairs not to exceed ninety 90 days unless otherwise authorized by the city administrator or designee the public works director shall also ensure inspection of work is completed d for any project costing ten thousand dollars $1000000 or more prior to the issuance of the permit the applicant shall be required to file with the administrative services department a corporate surety bond certified check or cash deposit in the amount of ten thousand dollars $1000000 or an amount equal to the estimated construction costs whichever is greater as a guarantee of faithful performance e for any project costing less than ten thousand dollars $1000000 the applicant shall agree to liquidated damages for delay over the stated or amended completion date in the amount of one hundred fifty dollars $15000 per day if cut is under three hundred 300 feet in length three hundred dollars $30000 per day if between three hundred 300 and five hundred 500 feet and five hundred dollars $50000 per day if over five hundred 500 feet in length  5102010   3 2122018 editors note  adopted  deleted the former enacted a new set out herein the former to removal of earth sand or gravel from streets and derived from part 1984 prior code  269   protection of existing improvements the applicant holding the permit for a project shall be responsible for the protection repair or replacement of all improvements which exist within the limits of the construction area  5102010   3 2122018 editors note  adopted  deleted the former enacted a new set out herein the former to barricades and lights and derived from    performance of work all work performed pursuant to the issuance of an excavation permit shall be done as follows a where trench structure excavation requires the removal of curb gutter concrete sidewalks or asphaltic or concrete pavement by means of backhoes graders or loaders the asphalt or concrete shall be cut before any excavating in a straight line parallel to the edge of the excavation and along existing control joints in concrete surfaces b when trench excavation is performed by a trencher asphalt pavement need not be cut prior to excavating operations however should trenching operations begin to pull lift andor tear existing asphalt pavement the trenching operation shall be discontinued until the asphalt is cut parallel to the edge of the excavation the city shall retain sole authority to determine whether the asphalt shall be cut prior to any excavating the minimum width of pavement removal for utilities greater than six 6 feet in depth shall not be less than eight 8 feet unless otherwise approved by the city all necessary corners shall be cut at not more than a fortyfivedegree angle to the trench excavation c asphalt patches shall be squared as much as possible to eliminate jagged edges and multiple sided patches patches within twelve 12 inches of existing concrete surfaces eg curb and gutter sidewalk manhole or valve diamonds shall be removed and the patch squared to provide neat straight grade lines for a symmetrical foursided patch existing abutting asphalt shall be rotomilled to approximately half of its existing depth but not more than two 2 inches and not less than one 1 inch the asphalt patch shall be placed in two 2 lifts with the bottom lift matching the rotomilled edge of the existing asphalt on all four 4 sides existing asphalt edges and rotomilled surfaces shall be sprayed with tack oil immediately before placement of the asphalt patch the finished patch shall match the grade and configuration of the existing asphalt and shall be completed approximately onequarter 14 inch above the elevationgrade of the existing asphalt street d repairs to existing streets paved with reinforced portland cement concrete paving pccp shall be completed to existing control joints applicant shall submit a detailed plan for cutting removing and replacing pccp streets prior to beginning work the plan shall be reviewed and approved by the public works director or city engineer e upon completion of the work all surplus construction materials and debris shall be removed leaving the entire site free clean and in a neat condition f the applicant or his agent shall be responsible for the removal and replacement of the concrete curb gutter and sidewalk and pavement and such shall be made within seven 7 working days after backfill is completed g all excavation backfilling and resurfacing work shall be performed by the contractor of record upon completion of the work the applicant or his agent shall give immediate notice to the city that such work has been completed h the applicant shall assume the responsibility for any damage to underground facilities caused by the trenching backfilling resurfacing or any other activities of the work i where excavations occur in unpaved surfaces the area shall be restored by placing a minimum of two 2 inches of stabilized gravel on the surface of the excavation j all topsoil and sod removed by the applicant shall be replaced k as a condition of the permit the applicant shall guarantee his work for a period of one 1 year from the date of final completion of the work if settlement equal to or greater than onehalf 12 inch or pavement separation equal to or greater than onequarter 14 inch occurs at the site of the excavation or immediately adjacent thereto at any time within one 1 year from the date of final completion of the original restoration the applicant shall be responsible for repairing such settled or separated areas in accordance with the directions of the public works director or city engineer  5102010 editors note  adopted  deleted the former enacted a new set out herein the former to restoration of surface and derived from part 1984 prior code  2611   routing traffic a the applicant or his agent shall take appropriate measures to assure that during the performance of the excavation work traffic conditions shall be maintained as nearly normal as practicable at all times b the city engineer or public works director may permit the closing of streets to all traffic for a period of time prescribed by himher if in hisher opinion it is necessary c excavations which traverse a street shall be limited to onehalf 12 the width of the street at any one time unless an emergency situation exists which requires that the entire width of the street be excavated  5102010   time for completion payment and appeal a in the event that the necessary repairs are not being accomplished expeditiously in accordance with the time period set forth in the permit or if the work on an excavation has ceased or is abandoned without due cause the city may after ten 10 working days from the date of issuing a certified letter to the holder of the permit so notifying correct the work backfill the excavation and effect all restoration as required by this chapter the city may employ private contractors to assist in the repair of the public improvement all costs and fees for the repairs performed will be borne by the applicant b in the event settlement of an excavation occurs within two 2 years of the date of final restoration and the applicant is notified of such settlement or pavement separation the applicant shall accomplish the required restoration or repair within the time limit specified by the city thereafter if the work has not been accomplished the city may complete the restoration or repair including by employing private contractors to assist in the repair of the settled public improvement all costs and fees for the repairs performed will be borne by the applicant c after compilation of the costs and charges incurred by the city for the repair of the public improvements a twenty percent 20% administrative fee if private contractors are utilized and liquidated damages as outlined in section b the city shall mail by certified mail return receipt requested to the responsible owner of the property a statement of the outstanding balance owed by the owner to the city for the repairs or restoration such balance shall be due and owing not more than thirty 30 days following the mailing of the notice d if the owner of the property wishes to contest the amount that was expended on the repairs or restoration he or she may file a written notice of appeal in person or by certified mail with the city clerk within ten 10 business days from the date of mailing of the statement of charges if no appeal is filed within that period the appeal shall be deemed waived and the statement amount shall be immediately due and owing to the city e if the owner files an appeal of the amount owed then the matter shall be set for hearing with city council within twenty 20 days from the date the notice is received by the clerk f if payment is not made within thirty 30 days of the demand the city will exhaust the means available under c of this chapter and no additional permits shall be issued to the applicant until payment has been made by the applicant in addition the city may proceed to collect any of the costs due and owing in any manner allowed by law including but not limited to the following and which shall be in addition to any other penalty imposable under this chapter or any other lawful statute i placing a lien against the property and filed with converse county  ii referral to a collection agency  iii reducing costs to judgment  or iv making the costs a special assessment or lien on the property involved  4 2122018 editors note  4 adopted feb 12 201 amended   in its entirety to read as herein set out former   pertained to time for completion and derived from  adopted    applicability and enforcement a the provisions of this chapter shall apply to all matters affecting or relating to the maintenance of public improvements and the abatement of nuisances relating to public improvements b the public works director or designee shall be responsible for enforcing the provisions of this chapter  5 2122018 street names and street addresses   street namesdesignated a official street names shall be as designated by the governing body by any of the following methods 1 by its approval of an annexation plat or subdivision plat with street names within the annexed or subdivided area shown thereon  or 2 the name may be designated or changed by ordinance following a public hearing held before the city council not less than fifteen 15 days before the public hearing legal notice of the hearing shall be mailed by first class mail to the owners of all properties located along the subject street and to the developers and other parties deemed appropriate who may have an interest in the original street name notice of the hearing shall be published twice in a newspaper of general circulation with the first notice appearing at least ten 10 days prior to the public hearing b where a street spans center street or an extended line thereof the street name shall include the appropriate north or south designation as it is situated relative to center street or its extension similarly where a street spans first street or an extended line thereof the street name shall include the appropriate east or west designation as it is situated relative to first street or its extension c official street names within the city limits shall be shown on current city maps prepared and kept by the douglas planning department part 1999   street nameplates except where made the responsibility of others as a condition of subdivision or development the nameplates for streets shall be provided and erected at the corners of the appropriate streets by and at the expense of the city part 1999   designating street addresses street addresses shall be designated by the douglas planning department which shall keep a map showing the proper number and location of all street addresses so designated part 1999   schedule for determining street addresses street addresses shall be assigned for every residence and for every building unless such building is accessory to a main building on the same lot and may be assigned to any lot resulting from an approved subdivision a on streets running generally north and south 1 address assignments on the east side of the street shall be odd numbers address assignments on the west side of the street shall be even numbers 2 as a street extends north and south from center street the hundreds digit of any address on such street shall correspond to the block count the subject address is from center street for example an address located in the third block north or south of center street will be in the three hundred block where center street does not extend east or west far enough to intersect a northsouth running street the hundred block of that street will be determined from an imaginary extension of center street for these purposes a block means the section of a street between two consecutive intersecting streets b on streets running generally east and west 1 address assignments on the south side of the street shall be odd numbers address assignments on the north side of the street shall be even numbers 2 as a street extends east and west from first street the hundreds digit of any address on such street shall correspond to the block count said address is from first street for example an address located in the third block east or west of first street will be in the three hundred block where first street does not extend north or south far enough to intersect an eastwest running street the hundred block of that street will be determined from an imaginary extension of first street for these purposes a block means the section of a street between two consecutive intersecting streets c where the layout of a street is irregular or unusual a strict interpretation of subsections a and b of this section may not be applicable in such cases address assignments shall be made with the douglas planning directors concurrence which best meet the intent of this code and preserve the established address pattern of the area d beginning with xoo and xol on the even and odd numbered sides of a block respectively where x is the hundreds digit each potential address provided for by this section shall cover twenty 20 feet fronting on the street to which it applies except in the fairview addition to the city each number shall cover twentyfive 25 feet of frontage addresses actually assigned shall be those corresponding to near the center of the subject lot or building part 1999   display of street addressrequired a it shall be the duty of the owner and occupants of every residence building or construction site to have placed thereon and to maintain the street address assigned to it as provided in this code and as further set forth in this section b prior to commencing the construction of any building on a site on which the assigned street address is not otherwise properly displayed such address shall be displayed on a temporary sign placed on the site in accordance with the provisions of this code and shall continue to be so displayed until replaced with permanent markings c street addresses shall be permanently marked in accordance with this code within thirty 30 days following 1 the annexation of the territory upon which the building rests  2 construction of any residence or other building  3 a written request by the douglas planning director d address markings shall be repaired or replaced within thirty 30 days after being removed or becoming defaced or destroyed or in any way not complying with the specifications given in this code part 1999   street address markingsspecifications for the purposes of this chapter street addresses for all buildings or building construction sites shall be marked in accordance with the following specifications a except for multiunit residential buildings no building shall be marked with more than one 1 address  b unless the building is not visible from the street or the address display is temporary as provided in the markings shall be displayed on a conspicuous place on that portion of the building that faces and is clearly visible from the street to which the address relates  c address markings shall be of a color with a contrasting background with characters a minimum of four 4 inches in height and one 1 inch in width in any case sufficiently large and plain to be clearly legible from the street  d permanent address markings on sites not having a suitable place to display the address on the building and temporary address markings shall be displayed on a sign not less than three 3 nor more than four 4 feet in height located on the subject property in a conspicuous place that faces and is clearly visible from the street to which the address relates at the main point of access to such street  e where a site or building contains multiple tenant spaces suites or similarly designated areas the designations for such spaces suites etc shall be similarly marked part 1999   defacing or injuring street or address markers any person moving defacing altering chipping or injuring in any way the street markers or other property belonging to the city or any address marking in use to satisfy the requirements of this chapter without approval of the city shall be guilty of a misdemeanor part 1999   address markingsfailure to install maintain or replacepenalties any person failing to install replace or maintain an address marking as required by this code or failing to remove address numbers not assigned in accordance with these provisions within thirty 30 days following written notification by the planning director to do so shall be subject to a fine of one dollar $100 for each day the failure continues from the date of first notification part 1999 parks parkways and recreational grounds   applicability of chapter this chapter shall apply to and within all parks parkways and recreational grounds within the town whether owned by the town of douglas any park or recreation district or any governmental or quasigovernmental or public corporation or entity  1981   definitions as used in this chapter park means any place for the resort of the public for recreation but shall not include any grounds or premises owned by any person corporation or business entity where the public is admitted for a charge made by such person corporation or entity for the purpose of private profit  1981   swimming in unlawful areas it is unlawful to swim in any lake or body of water in any park parkway or recreational grounds within the town save and except established swimming pools during the hours when the same are regularly open to the public or in areas of lakes or bodies of water specifically set aside for swimming by the authority having jurisdiction of the park parkway or recreational ground in which such lake or body of water is located during hours designated and authorized by such authority  1981   swimming pools it is unlawful for any person other than a person authorized by the authority having jurisdiction over a swimming pool to enter in or upon any enclosed area or enclosure in which a swimming pool is located at any time or hour when the same is not open to the public  1981   fires in unauthorized areas it is unlawful to light make or use any fire except in those areas where fires are specifically authorized  provided however that this section shall not apply to authorized park city or recreation district employees acting in the scope of their employment  1981   driving or parking in parks and recreational areas it is unlawful for anyone other than authorized personnel to drive or park on lawns fields or any other places within any park parkway or recreational grounds within the town other than upon roadways or parking areas clearly construed and established for such purposes  1981   hours of operation the parks parkways and recreational areas which are the subject of this chapter within this town shall normally be opened daily to the public from five  in the morning until eleven  at night and it is unlawful for any person who is not an employee of the authority having jurisdiction over a particular park parkway or recreational area or of the town acting in the scope of his employment to be or remain in any such park parkway or area at any other time provided however a that the authority having jurisdiction over such park parkway or recreational ground may by permit or authorization first had or obtained or by regulation duly posted in the area affected extend to a later hour the nighttime closing hour with respect to particular area or parks parkways or recreational grounds and with respect to particular recreational activities in such parks parkways or areas  and b nothing contained in this section shall prevent or make unlawful the conduct of or attendance at duly authorized nighttime athletic events or activity in areas set aside and lighted for such events or activities by or with the permission of the authority having jurisdiction of such park parkway or recreational ground  c that this section shall not apply to townoperated overnight campgrounds as described in  1981   overnight camping facilities individuals who wish to use municipal campground facilities for overnight or short duration camping shall be subject to the following provisions a such facilities are designed for use by mobile homes travel trailers truck campers and tenting equipment and may be used by individuals for a maximum of fortyeight 48 hours without charge after which the campground is to be vacated by the individual  b individuals using such facilities shall be subject to all regulations duly posted concerning affected areas  c it is unlawful to violate the provisions of this section  1981 reserved all vacations of rightofway shall comply with the requirements of section 313 of the unified land development 1  editors note  adopted   repealed ch 1218   in its entirety  and set out provisions which read as set out herein former ch 1218 pertained to vacation of streets and alleys and was derived from part adopted 1994 trees and shrubs footnotes  2  prior history    purpose of chapter the purpose of this chapter is to promote and protect the safety of persons and property by providing for the regulation of the planting maintenance and removal of trees shrubs and other plants within the city part 2000 prior code  291   definitions as used in this chapter park trees means trees shrubs bushes and all other woody vegetation in public parks parkway means the area between the sidewalk and the curb that may include trees and other vegetation the parkway is the property of the city and responsibility of maintenance and care of the parkway lies with the property ownerresident street trees means trees shrubs bushes and all other woody vegetation on land lying between property lines on either side of all streets avenues or rightsofway with the city topping means the severe cutting back of limbs to stubs larger than three 3 inches in diameter within the crown of the tree to such a degree as to remove the normal canopy and disfigure the tree part 2000   parksrecreationcemetery division a duties and responsibilities the parksrecreationcemetery division of the public works department shall be responsible for the development and administration of a written plan for the care preservation pruning planting replanting removal or disposition of trees and shrubs in parks along streets and in other public areas and to prepare an annual update of said plan for presentation to the city council for their acceptance and approval the approved plan shall constitute the official comprehensive city tree plan for the city the division when requested by the city council shall report andor make recommendations on any special matter or question coming within the scope of its work b operation the parksrecreationcemetery division operates within the guidelines for all employees as set forth in the city human resources policies and procedures and the city health and safety policy the city administrator and the public works director shall serve in an advisory capacity to the parksrecreationcemetery division as it relates to the provisions of this chapter part 2000   street tree specifications a the planting of street trees shall comply with the specifications found in the unified land development plantings outside property lines 1 no trees or shrubs shall be planted grown cultivated maintained or permitted to be in or on that portion of any intersection which lies within the right angle formed by the projection of two 2 corner property lines 2 no hedges or similar plantings exceeding three 3 feet in height shall be permitted between the property line and the nearest street or curb line at any point within twenty 20 feet of the street or curb line of the intersecting street 3 in all districts specified for the installation of a sidewalk adjacent to the curb in accordance with the provisions of this chapter no trees or shrubs shall be planted at a distance less than five and onehalf 512 feet of the nearest curb or street line 4 in all areas where the sidewalk is not adjacent to the curb the planting of any trees or shrubs outside of the property line shall be in accordance with the regulations of the parksrecreationcemetery division of the public works department part 2000   8102015    maintenance a the parksrecreationcemetery division shall have the right to plant prune maintain and remove trees plants and shrubs within the lines of all streets alleys avenues parks and other public property as may be necessary to insure public safety to minimize the potential for damage to vehicles and equipment or to preserve or enhance the symmetry and beauty of such public property the parksrecreationcemetery division may cause or order to be removed any tree or part thereof which is in an unsafe condition or which by reason of its nature is injurious to sewer lines water lines or other public improvements or is infected with any injurious fungus insect or other pest this section does not prohibit the planting of street trees by adjacent property owners providing that the selection and location of said trees is in accordance with b tree topping it is unlawful as a normal practice for the parksrecreationcemetery division or any other person or firm to top any street tree park tree or other tree on public property trees severely damaged by storms or other causes or certain trees located under obstructions where other pruning practices are impractical may be exempted from this chapter at the determination of the parksrecreationcemetery division c pruning corner clearance every owner of any tree overhanging any street or rightofway within the city shall prune the branches so that such branches shall not obstruct the light from any street lamp or obstruct the view of any street intersection and so that there shall be a clear space of eight 8 feet above the surface of any sidewalk and fourteen 14 feet above the surface of any street or alley said owners shall remove all dead diseased or dangerous trees or broken or decayed limbs which constitute a menace to the safety of the public the parksrecreationcemetery division shall have the right to prune any tree or shrub on private property when it interferes with the proper spread of light along the street from a street light or interferes with visibility of any traffic control device or sign d dead or diseased tree removal on private property 1 declaring a nuisance the parksrecreationcemetery division shall have the right to cause the removal of any dead or diseased trees on private property within the city when such trees constitute a hazard to life and property or harbor insects or disease that constitute a potential threat to other trees within the city by declaring said trees a nuisance 2 notice to abate the parksrecreationcemetery division will provide the appropriate written notice to owners to abate such trees at their own expense within sixty 60 days after the date the notice is served 3 abatement by city in the event owners fail to comply with the provisions of the notice to abate the city shall have the authority to take such action as necessary to remove such trees the cost of removal shall be assessed against the property which constitutes a lien against the property e removal of stumps all stumps of street trees and park trees shall be removed below the surface of the ground so that the top of the stump shall not project above the surface of the ground f replacement of mature trees in the event of development that may infringe upon mature trees the following considerations are to be implemented 1 the city arborist shall review the plans for all developments proposed community development department the purpose of their review will be to determine whether or not there are existing trees that may be affected by such development they will determine the approximate age of such trees the historic significance of such trees the approximate monetary value of such trees and provide a recommendation on whether or not the development needs to be modified to avoid removal of such trees if no city arborist exists then the city shall contact a representative of the state forestry office who shall perform the same functions as stated within this section 2 if it is determined that any trees will need to be removed the developer shall contribute funding to the citys tree planting budget in an amount equal to the value of the trees to be removed as determined by the city arborist using established tree valuation calculations but not to exceed one thousand dollars $100000 per tree this amount shall be earmarked for tree replacement along public rightsofway in the absence of a city arborist a state forestry arborist will be contacted to determine the value part 2000 part 1984 prior code  293   4262016    compliance with chapterenforcement a interference with parksrecreationcemetery division it is unlawful for any person to prevent delay or interfere with the parksrecreationcemetery division or any of its agents while engaging in the planting cultivating mulching pruning spraying or removing of any street trees park trees or trees on private grounds as authorized in this chapter b licensing it is unlawful for any person or firm to engage in the business or occupation of pruning treating or removing street trees or park trees within the city without first applying for and procuring the appropriate contractors license in accordance with the provisions in of the douglas municipal no license shall be required of any public service company or city employee doing such work in the pursuit of their public service endeavors before any license shall be issued the applicant shall provide proof of liability insurance in the minimum amounts of fifty thousand dollars $5000000 for bodily injury and one hundred thousand dollars $10000000 for property damage indemnifying the city from any person injured or damage resulting from the pursuit of such endeavors as herein described c review by city council the city council shall have the right to review the conduct acts and decisions of the parksrecreationcemetery division any person may appeal any ruling or order of the parksrecreationcemetery division to the city council who may hear the matter and make final decision d penalty any person violating any provision of this chapter shall upon conviction or a plea of guilty be subject to a fine not to exceed seven hundred fifty dollars $75000 part 2000 part 1984 prior code  294 municipal cemeteries   burial in cemetery required it is unlawful for any person to be buried at any place within the city limits of the city other than in a lawfully established cemetery part 1998   cemetery names designated the names of the cemeteries owned by the city shall be douglas park cemetery located within the city and pioneer cemetery located north of the city and shall be referred to in this chapter as douglas municipal cemeteries part 1998   definitions as used in this chapter city administrator means the city administrator or his or her duly authorized designee nonresident means an individual group corporation or organization who does not reside within converse county resident means an individual group corporation or organization who resides within converse county part 1998   duties of the city administrator a the city administrator shall establish rules and regulations within the limitations of this chapter for the management operation and maintenance of the douglas municipal cemeteries such rules will be filed in the office of the city clerk and at the cemetery office upon adoption by resolution by the city council b the city administrator shall manage operate and maintain the douglas municipal cemeteries and see that no space in the municipal cemeteries is used or occupied in violation of this chapter or any rule or regulation promulgated under this chapter c the city administrator shall be charged with the duty of collecting all moneys due and payable to the city for the purchase of any section block lot or space in douglas municipal cemeteries and any other fees due and payable for burials or other services d the city administrator shall authorize all burial permits in douglas municipal cemeteries and shall ensure that graves are opened and excavated in the proper section block lot and space e the city administrator shall maintain records showing 1 when and to whom the sections lots and spaces are sold  2 the purchase price  3 to whom a burial permit is issued  and 4 such other information as shall be deemed advisable by the city council f the city administrator will permit no burial within the boundaries of the historic grave sites within the pioneer cemetery platted areas of the pioneer cemetery outside the historic grave sites may be used for burial if the city administrator finds that all of the expansion area in the douglas park cemetery has been exhausted part 1998   issuance of deeds a no deed for any section lot block or space in douglas municipal cemeteries will be issued and no title for same shall pass until all purchase charges payable to the city have been paid all deeds will be issued by the city clerk signed by the mayor and city clerk under the seal of the city b at the time a section lot block or space is purchased the city administrator or hisher designee may permit the purchaser to execute a promissory note for the citys charges to become due and payable on the last day of the next succeeding month without interest c delinquent notes shall bear interest at the maximum legal rate and no further credit shall be extended to the maker of any note which has not been paid within six 6 months from the date of execution at the end of the six 6 months if all fees are not paid the city shall reclaim all spaces and may retain payments made for such spaces part 1998   purchase price per space the city shall charge and receive payment for services provided as set forth in this section 1 infant section $10000 2 residents of converse county $20000 3 nonresidents of converse county $30000 4 perpetual care $10000 5 recording of deed as determined by the converse county clerks office 6 memorial marker permit $2500 part 2006 part 1998   10282013    2222016    perpetual care perpetual care charges for cemetery spaces as set forth in d of this chapter shall be set aside in a special fund invested in such lawful manner as deemed advisable and the revenue from such fund shall be used only for the purpose of perpetuating the care maintenance and upkeep of douglas municipal cemeteries part 1998   burial charges 1 open and close new grave a infant burial $10000 b cremations $10000 c all other burials $30000 2 disinterment cremains $15000 plus cremation opening and closing fees 3 disinterment all other $65000 plus opening and closing fees 4 reinterments $35000 plus opening and closing fees 5 6 in addition to the charges set forth in subsections 1 the following fees shall be assessed a services occurring outside scheduled working hours or days $25000 b services occurring on designated city holidays $50000 7 no additional burial services shall be provided by the city unless the scope of services and charges for such services are expressly agreed upon in advance with the city administrator 8 disinterment or reinterment services that require the additional use of heavy equipment as determined by the parks and recreation director andor the cemetery sexton may incur additional costs for such equipment used opening and closing fees will also apply in addition to disinterment and reinterment fees 9 the city of douglas has no authority to determine what additional fees may be charged by any third party or vault company pertaining to any disinterment or reinterment into the douglas park cemetery part 2006 part 1998   2222016    burial permit required no burial will be permitted in any municipal cemetery until a burial permit has been issued showing that all purchase and burial fees have been paid the burial permit shall also indicate the ownerpurchaser section lot block and space date and time of funeral and any other information applicable for official records part 1998   disinterment and reinterment a permit for disinterment and reinterment shall be required prior to disinterment of a dead body or stillbirth from one space to another space within the douglas park cemetery or to any location outside of the douglas park cemetery except as authorized by the state department of health regulations a court order or otherwise provided by state law the permit shall be issued by the local registrar or a licensed funeral director embalmer or other person acting as such upon proper application part 1998  3142013   setting vaults vaults are not required for burial in douglas cemeteries if vaults are desired the setting of vaults shall be done under the guidelines as set forth in the rules and regulations governing the douglas municipal cemeteries part 1998   installation of monuments no monuments markers or structures used to mark or identify the location of an interment shall be placed within douglas municipal cemeteries until a monument permit has been issued by the cemetery sexton and certification of ownership verified by the city administrator part 1998   decoration of graves graves may be decorated and decorations removed under the guidelines as set forth in the rules and regulations governing the douglas municipal cemeteries part 1998   resale of cemetery lots the resale of cemetery lots is prohibited except back to the city such resale to the city shall be at the rate set by ordinance at the time of resale a quit claim deed will be executed by the seller and recorded by the city the cost of recording the deed will be borne by the seller part 1998   errors the city administrator shall have the right to correct any errors that may be made by himher or hisher designees either in making interments disinterments and removals or in the description transfer and conveyance of any interment property this may be done either by directing the canceling of such conveyance and substituting and conveying in lieu thereof other interment property of equal value or by refunding the amount of money paid on account of the purchase in the event such error shall involve the interment of the remains of any person in such property the city reserves the right to remove and transfer such remains so interred to such other property of equal value and similar locations as may be substituted in lieu thereof the city city administrator or other designees shall in no way be liable for any delay in the interment of a body where a protest to the interment has been made or where there has been a failure to comply with the ordinance or rules and regulations the city administrator shall be under no duty to recognize any protest of interment unless it is in writing and filed in the office of the city clerk part 1998 specific rules and regulations   authority to promulgate the use of streets sidewalks and public places shall be subject to such specific rules and regulations as may be promulgated by the chief of police fire chief or city administrator  provided that said rule or rules shall first be approved by the city council and that notice of such rule or rules is legibly posted at the location where said rule or regulation is to be enforced violation of such a posted rule or regulation shall be punishable by a fine of not more than seven hundred fifty dollars $75000  title 13  public services division i  water system general requirements and information   duties of governing body subject to the laws relating to public utilities the governing body shall fix all rates for water charges tap fees and for services outside the corporate limits of the town and make regulations for the collection of the fees and charges  1983   powers and duties of town administrator a the town administrator or hisher authorized representative shall enforce all necessary rules regulations and penalties to enforce the collection of fees or for the protection of the property and rights pertaining to the towns waterworks system this authority shall include the power to make administrative rules or regulations as may be necessary to conserve the water supply and to prevent waste and unnecessary use of water including water restrictions b the town administrator or hisher designated representative is authorized to issue a shutoff notice to any person who is two 2 months delinquent in payment of any water bill such persons water shall be shut off pursuant to the bill is not paid in full following shutoff notice  1983   powers and duties of utility department director the utility department director shall be responsible for the distribution and treatment of the towns water system from the source of supply to service lines on the property side of the curb stop  1983   interfering or tampering with waterworkspolluting water supply a no unauthorized person shall in any way interfere or tamper with any part of the towns water system nor shall they do anything that will in any manner pollute or cause to pollute the water supply any person found guilty of polluting or tampering with the towns water supply shall be subject to a maximum fine of seven hundred fifty dollars $75000 b no unauthorized person shall in any manner tamper with deface or injure any fire hydrant nor shall the same be obstructed by any person in any manner so that free access to such hydrant cannot be readily had at all times for firefighting purposes any person found guilty of these acts shall be subject to a maximum fine of seven hundred fifty dollars $75000  1983   maintenance of service lines a all property owners and consumers of water shall keep and maintain the service line beginning at the property side of the curb stop and shall keep the line in good repair and protect it from frost at their own expense b the town shall not be responsible for payment of any claim resulting from the breakage of any pipe meter or appurtenance attached thereto if the breakage occurs on the property side of the curb stop  1983   water metersrequired a all water delivered to any water users by means of the water system of the city shall be measured by meters b each singlefamily dwelling multifamily building business structure or mobile home park shall have a separate water meter condominiums townhouses andor duplex units shall be considered singlefamily units and shall have separate meters and shutoffs if each unit is individually owned part 1997   1983   installation of metersgenerally a as included in the fees set forth in the city shall supply all meters installed in the city water system all meters shall be installed with remote readout located on the outside of the structure or at the meter pit and accessible at all times to authorized personnel b meters shall be a minimum of threefourths 34 inch inlet size all meters installed prior to  and located inside structures shall be installed and maintained in such a way that access is available at all reasonable hours no pipes or other objects shall be installed in front of or adjacent to the meter sufficient room for removal of the meter must be available swivel connections shall be used and at least one 1 inch flexibility must be maintained in pipes to which meters are connected for proper removal for maintenance unless approved by utility department director all water meters installed at structures constructed after  shall be installed in meter pits as specified in the latest edition of the city amendments and supplements to the wyoming public works standard specifications meters two 2 inches in diameter and larger shall be installed in reinforced concrete vaults  the design of the meter vaults shall be submitted to the city for approval prior to construction c a gate valve must be installed in front of and behind the meter in order to allow isolation of the meter d any compound meter installed shall be installed horizontally to allow for proper repair and maintenance e each meter installed shall be protected by a cityapproved seal the seal shall not be broken without the utility department directors approval splices of any type will not be allowed in any readout cable and shall be considered as tampering with city property no person shall tamper with readout cables or meter seals install an illegal tap bypass or in any way remove water from the citys system without going proper metered facility any person found guilty of a violation of this subsection shall be subject to a fine not to exceed seven hundred fifty dollars $75000 part 2008 part 1997   1983   right of access to meters the utility department director meter technician or other authorized personnel of the city shall have free access at all reasonable hours to enter any premises where water is used for the purpose of ascertaining any violation of any provisions of this chapter and to read inspect repair or remove for testing any water meter part 2008  1983   ownership of metersmaintenance a all meters and remote readouts including cable are the property of the city b the owner of the property upon which a meter is located shall assure that such meter is at all times in good working order and shall contact the utility department director to cause the meter to be repaired or replaced the property owner shall bear all cost of maintenance except for normal wear from operation c city utility personnel shall remove and replace the meter if found defective and unless damaged by the property owner or occupant shall do so at no cost to the property owner d if the property owner requests a test to verify meter accuracy the meter shall be removed and tested by city personnel all costs associated with testing shall be the responsibility of the property owner if no malfunction of the meter is found if the meter is found to be faulty the city shall pay all costs of meter testing part 2008 part 1997   1983   responsibility for taps or connections to water mains a all taps or connections into any water main of the city shall be completed under the direction and supervision of an authorized employee of the city and subject to material and method approval by the city no substitutions are allowed unless approval in writing is granted by the utility department director b any cost for taps including excavation materials tools backfill compaction and resurfacing of streets and replacement of curb gutter and sidewalks shall be done at the full expense of the property owner developer or contractor part 2008  1983   curb stopsinstallation a curb stops shall be furnished and installed by a contractor licensed to work in the city for all structures to be served with water b singlefamily dwellings and businesses shall have curb stops installed within five 5 feet of the property line at the back of the sidewalk if space allows  or within the sidewalk if the sidewalk abuts a building set level with the sidewalk and such curb stops shall be of a ferrous metallic composition to allow for location by a magnetic or conductance locator c multiplefamily dwellings shall have one 1 curb stop located within the public rightofway as determined by the city which shall provide shutoff service to the entire facility part 2008  1983   bulk water a no water shall be delivered in bulk to any user or customer for any reason for transportation within or outside the city unless such water shall be obtained from the citys fill station at the public works building no bulk water shall be taken from any fire hydrant for fees refer to b utility department director may grant permission for temporary installation of any approved mobile fill station provided a separate shutoff valve vacuum breaker and meter is provided by the user such permission shall be granted in writing for fees refer to part 2008  1983 crossconnection and backflow control   purpose the purpose of this chapter is to comply with the federal safe drinking water act of 197 the department of environmental quality water quality rules and regulations the international plumbing to meet the following goals a to protect the public potable water supply of the city from the possibility of contamination or pollution by isolating within its customers internal distribution systems such contaminants or pollutants which could backflow  to back siphon  into the public water system  b to promote the elimination or control of existing crossconnections actual or potential between the customers inplant potable water systems and nonpotable systems plumbing fixtures and industrial piping systems  c to provide for the maintenance of a continuing program of crossconnection control which will systematically prevent the contamination or pollution of all potable water systems part 2004   definitions the following definitions shall apply to this chapter a approved means accepted by the utility department director as meeting an applicable specification stated or cited in this chapter or as suitable for the proposed use b auxiliary water supply means any water supply on or available to the water users premises other than the citys approved public potable water supply c backflow means the flow of water or other liquids mixtures or substances under positive or reduced pressure into the distribution pipes of the potable water supply from any source other than its intended source d backflow preventer means an approved device or means designed to prevent backflow or back siphonage events from contaminating the potable water supply system the most common devices are air gap reduced pressure principal device double check valve assembly pressure vacuum breaker atmospheric vacuum breaker hose bibb vacuum breaker residential dual check double check with intermediate atmospheric vent and barometric loop e back pressure means a condition in which the water users system pressure is greater than the citys system pressure f back siphonage means the flow or water or other liquids mixtures or substances into the distribution pipes of the potable water supply system source other than its intended source caused by the sudden reduction of pressure in the potable water supply system g certified backflow protection assembly tester means a person who has passed an approved backflow protection assembly testers certification examination h check valve means a selfclosing assembly which is designed to permit the flow of fluids in one direction a single check valve is not an approved backflow prevention assembly i containment means the practice of installing approved backflow prevention devices at the water service connection of the water user in order to protect the public water supply from any backflow from the water users system j contamination means an impairment of a public water supply by the introduction or admission of any foreign substance which degrades the quality of the potable water or creates a health hazard k crossconnection means any actual or potential connection between a potable water supply and any other source or system it is possible to introduce contamination into the system l domestic services means services using potable water for ordinary living processes not for commercial or industrial uses fire protection systems with antifreeze or other chemicals heating systems etc examples may include residences churches office buildings schools etc m dual check means a device conforming to the american society of sanitary engineering standards no 104 consisting of two 2 independently acting check valves dual check valves are allowed only for residential water service connections that have a low hazard potential with back pressure or back siphonage under continuous pressure n fixture isolation means a method of backflow prevention in which a backflow preventer is located to correct a crossconnection at the fixture location rather than at a water service entrance o hazard classification means a determination by a hazard classification surveyor as to high hazard or low hazard and the potential cause of backflow as either back pressure or back siphonage p high hazard means a situation created when any substance which is or may be introduced into a public water supply poses a threat to public health the spread of disease or pathogenic organisms or any other public health concern q low hazard means a situation created when any substance which is or may be introduced into a public water supply does not pose a threat to public health but which does adversely affect the aesthetic quality of the potable water r water service connection means any waterline or pipe connected to a distribution supply main or pipe for the purpose of conveying water to a water users system s water user means any entity whether public or private with a water service connection to a public water supply the water user is also identified as a customer of a public water supply t water user system means that portion of the users water system between the water service connection and the point of use this system includes all pipes conduits tanks fixtures and appurtenances used to convey store or utilize water provided by the public water supply part 2004   responsibility a the city has the responsibility of owning operating and maintaining the public water system beginning at the source of supply and including adequate treatment facilities the public water distribution system and service piping ending at the point of delivery to the consumers water system service connection curb stop b the city shall develop adopt by resolution and implement a crossconnection control program in accordance with the minimum requirements set forth by the wyoming department of environmental quality the city shall exercise reasonable informed judgment in assessing the degree of hazard posed to the public water system by all water users being served c the city building official shall be responsible for reviewing building plans and inspection of plumbing as it is installed so as to prevent crossconnections from being designed and built into structures within the citys jurisdiction the building officials inspection responsibility begins at the curb stop connection or water meter pit and continues throughout the entire extent of the customers potable water system approved backflow prevention devices shall be indicated on the construction plans as determined by the degree of hazard that the inspector reasonably determines will be present and such devices shall be properly installed d the water user has the primary responsibility for preventing pollutants and contaminants from entering hisher potable water system or the public water system the water users responsibility starts at the point of delivery service connection curb stop and includes all of hisher internal water system the water user at hisher own expense shall install operate test and maintain approved backflow prevention devices as required by this chapter part 2004   degree of hazard the city recognizes the threat to the public water system arising from crossconnections all threats will be classified based upon the degree of hazard of the crossconnection and the cause of the potential backflow hazards shall be classified as high hazard or low hazard the potential cause of the backflow shall be identified as being back siphonage or back pressure part 2004   residential water service connections residential water service connections shall be considered to be low hazard back siphonage connections unless determined otherwise by a hazard classification residential dual check devices for structures existing at the time of passage of the ordinance codified in this chapter shall be replaced under a program as referenced in b of this chapter and funded water department capital replacement fund installation of residential dual check devices shall be installed as water meters are replaced throughout the community with the goal of installing all such systems within sixty 60 months from passage of the ordinance codified in this chapter part 2004   new residential water users all new residential developments will be required to install a residential dual check device at the water users expense downstream of the water meter before any certificate of occupancy will be issued for the structure the water user shall be notified that installation of a backflow prevention assembly device results in a potential closed plumbing system within hisher residence as such provisions may have to be made by the water user to provide for thermal expansion within hisher closed loop system part 2004   commercial industrial or other high hazard water users a commercial or industrial water users shall at their own expense install maintain and test or have tested any and all backflow preventers beyond the water service connection pursuant to b commercial or industrial water service connections shall be considered to be high hazard back pressure connections unless determined otherwise by the hazard classification for premises existing prior to the adoption of the ordinance codified in this chapter the city will perform evaluation and inspections of plans andor premises under its crossconnection program 1 if such water users are determined to be low hazard the water user shall be required to install appropriate crossconnection device within sixty 60 months of passage of the ordinance codified in this chapter 2 if such water users are determined to be high hazard the city shall notify such water user by letter of the need to install a suitable crossconnection device or to correct any existing faulty crossconnection device installation the method of achieving the correction and the time allowed for the installation or correction to be made in no case shall a high hazard water service connection be
